intro: Daucus scabricaulis, commonly known as the rough-hair parsley, is a flowering plant native to western North America. It is characterized by its finely hairy stems and leaves with a distinctive, fern-like appearance. The plant produces small, yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the Apiaceae family. It thrives in dry, rocky habitats and is often found in open woodlands or along streambanks. Due to its ornamental value and ecological role, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens.
